data.title: Death on High Mountain (1969)
data.meta_description: Braddock is an influential and highly respected citizen of the town of Two Arrows. He also represents a group of Mexican outlaws led by Valiente. Braddock plans an important robbery with only two young men, Loring and Parker, standing in the way of the bandits.
data.text:
The final film of director Fernando Cerchio, Death on High Mountain is an extremely inconsequential comedy with a very high body count. It also, somehow, shifts from very dumb to still dumb but also genuinely funny about halfway through its running time. While it could well be that I just got worn down and finally had to give in, the reality is that Peter Lee Lawrence was born to play cheeky shit-disturbers — particularly when they're named 'Loring Vandervelt' — and he and Argentine actor Luis Dávila (playing Mark Harrison) have surprisingly good, genial chemistry.

I could summarize the plot, but it really doesn't matter. Suffice it to say that there's intense buffoonery from a gang of bandits-cum-revolutionaries, shady behavior…

Peter Lee Lawrence western-vehicle that shows many of the tropes and conventions of the westerns the actor (and the films he was casted in), in spades. Released in 1969, a very transitional year for spaghetti westerns, the film also shows the general mood of that transitional period of time, specifically, a tongue-in-cheek mixture of comedy and violence.

The film is almost a loose sequel-remake of Peter Lee Lawrence's previous 1967 western-mystery hybrid Killer Caliber .32. Both films feature actress Agnès Spaak in a role of a duplicitous saloon girl, focus on a buttload of missing cash stolen from a bank, the same saloon interior set, and overall the same M.O. of filmmaking.

(Most likely) due to Peter Lee Lawrence's... less…
